bboxes.raw_text:
MIAMI, Fla. A 3o-year-old
Jamaican who shot and killed two
officers during wild gun battle
at crawded Miami International
Airport was charged with two
counts of first degree murder.


Lloyd Ashley Cuff. a Negro,
was being deported Saturday when
he grabbed a .38 from Miami
policeman Carlos Stuteville and
killed him with one shot in the
chest.


Screaming, he pivoted and fired
at Detroit plainclothesman,
Paul Chisenhall, killing him with
a bullet in the chest and another
in the skull.

JAMAICAN KILLS TWO OFFICERS


AT AIR MIAMI AIRPORT

Another uniformed Miami po-
nceman, Bill Pearson, heard
the commotion, ran into the
concourse and fired six shots
at the fleeing Jamaican. All
missed. Pearson threw Cuff to
the floor and held him until
other security officers arrived.


An airline employee said the
two officers we're taking Cuff
down a conc curse when the shoot
ing Started.


Police said Cuff jumped ship
from the Elizabeth Schultz last
week in Detroit and was being
deported to Kingston.

TUCSON Rubin Salter, %
yr. old bachelor, has become
the first Negro in Tucson to
practice law.


A native of Freeport, ILL.,, Sal
ter holds a bachelors and a
law degree from the University
of Arizona.


He served two years in the US.
Army and worked as a service
station attendant, recreation
leader and mail carrier before
completing his studies.


The energetic man held full
time night job at Hughes Air
craft Co., data processing
section, until he was laid off
last fall.


Later he was a clerk for Tue
son attorney Ted Petersen.


When interviewed Salter said
he wanted to be a good lawyer
not Negro lawyer.

PHILADELPHIA A group
of Negro Republican leaders, in
Guiding some who we're dissatis-
fled with the nomination of Sena-
tor G oldwater at the COP national
convention last month, have held
a top secret committee.


John Clay. Philadelphia at
torney, said they met to form a
permanent organization within
our party. He continued that the
group wanted Negroes to have
more voice in party policies.

Mrs. George (Minnie) Meares.
wife of the newly elected grand
basileus of the Omega Psi Phi
fraternity. leads a double life.


She is proud of her housewife
title and equally proud of her
position with the New York State
Department of Labor as an en-
ployment interviewer and dis
elimination investigator.


Mrs. Meares and her husband
have a long record of achieve
ments in the field of human re-
lations. She is active in many
civic and social organizations,
including the Delta Sigma Theta
Sorority.


The Meares lived in Phoenix
during the l94Os, when Mr..
Meares was the executive secre-
tary of the Phoenix Urban League.

Leon Jordan, 2l35 E. Corona,
biology instructor at Comeback
High, left Wednesday, August 26.
for Denver.


He was one of the team of writ
ers who prepared a new biology
textbook this summer at the Uni
versity of Colorado in Boulder.


He will spend several days in
Denver briefing secondary teach
ers in the Denver school system
on the utilization of new materi-
ais in the newly published volume.

WASHINGTON twenty-five
per cent of male Negro teen
ayers in the US. labor force
are out of work, according to
government statistics obtained.


In addition, the jobless rate
among Negro teen-age boys,
which was only slightly higher

than that among their white
counterparts 10 years ago, is now
nearly twice as high. The jobless
rate for both groups has gronw,
as was expected because of the
teen-age population explosion,
but the Negro rate has grown
more rapidly.

Is Per Cent Of Male
Negro Teenugers Idle

Western hospitality the theme welcome party held
Tuesday the home of Mr. and Mrs. William WARREN 52l6
10th Place.


Honoed the newly elected grand basieus of the Omega
Psi Phi fraternity George Meares and his wife, visiting
the following grand conclave in Denver last week.


Top photo Fraters the host chapter Phi oa with their
officer.


Front from William Warren, DR.. David Solomon
George Meae basus Dave Cook and Leonard Wburn
Second Willie Johnson Nathaniel Robinson, John Henry
George Greene Sylvester Mabry Earl Oats LIB Livingston.
Phi Iota baseus Joshua Bursh Travis Williams and Rev. A.
G. Kendrick.

Accolades given Mary Bene School recently baseball
The highest league games
spoons by the Harmon Park Mems Club.


Shown banquet honoring the champions Park
from left Pat Romero Bethe coach which Class
honors Gil Chavez Harmon Park LEADER Famuae
speaker Rutherford Mayed Club PRESIDENT
Anderson Betune Class COACH Davis,
Bethune Class team coach.

Wearing solemn face is Irwin Archer. of Mr. and Mrs.
Irwin Archer, Sr. PIP E. Parkway DR..


He submits Mrs. Ida Steele secretary Sheraton
Park Primary School, she fills enrolment forms.


Irwin Sheraton Park
School and he feels he his around the first
grade Irwin enjoyed learning the said he likes
school.
